citations.narrative:
* The written program of veterinary care is incomplete for five dogs. It does not include a schedule for sampling and
treating parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm). The program of veterinary
care does not have an identifiable frequency/schedule for the number of dogs that will be tested. Under section B,
parasite control program treatment plan for Ectoparasites it states, “Frontline Plus”, Blood Parasites it states, “Heart
guard” and under Intestinal Parasites it states “Panacur and Heart guard”. In addition, dosage rates that would be
administered to the dogs or puppies were not recorded. Failure to have a schedule for parasite sampling may cause the
animals to not be adequately protected from diseases and parasites. Ectoparasites including fleas, intestinal parasites
such as coccidia and giardia, and heartworm, are common causes of disease in dogs and, if left undetected and not
properly treated, can lead to serious illness. The written program of veterinary care must address the requirements for
adequate veterinary care and include vaccinations and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests in
accordance with a schedule approved by the veterinarian. Correct by 9/15/24.

* The USDA Program of Veterinary Care form 7002 A was incomplete for five dogs. Under section C “Preventive Care
and Treatment Plan” all schedules are recorded as “Check Daily”. This is not a complete description of what will be
provided to the dogs. When the program of vet care is missing information, it is not considered to be adequate veterinary
care. The program of veterinary care must address the preventive care and treatment of all dogs to ensure healthy and
unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. These plans are important to
maintain the health and well-being of the dogs and must be addressed in the written program of veterinary care signed by
the attending veterinarian. Correct by 9/15/24
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* The written program of veterinary care is incomplete for five dogs. It does not include a schedule for sampling and 
treating parasites and other pests (including fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and heartworm). The program of veterinary 
care does not have an identifiable frequency/schedule for the number of dogs that will be tested. Under section B, 
parasite control program treatment plan for Ectoparasites it states, “Frontline Plus”, Blood Parasites it states, “Heart 
guard” and under Intestinal Parasites it states “Panacur and Heart guard”. In addition, dosage rates that would be 
administered to the dogs or puppies were not recorded. Failure to have a schedule for parasite sampling may cause the 
animals to not be adequately protected from diseases and parasites. Ectoparasites including fleas, intestinal parasites 
such as coccidia and giardia, and heartworm, are common causes of disease in dogs and, if left undetected and not 
properly treated, can lead to serious illness. The written program of veterinary care must address the requirements for 
adequate veterinary care and include vaccinations and sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests in 
accordance with a schedule approved by the veterinarian. Correct by 9/15/24. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* The USDA Program of Veterinary Care form 7002 A was incomplete for five dogs. Under section C “Preventive Care 
and Treatment Plan” all schedules are recorded as “Check Daily”. This is not a complete description of what will be 
provided to the dogs. When the program of vet care is missing information, it is not considered to be adequate veterinary 
care. The program of veterinary care must address the preventive care and treatment of all dogs to ensure healthy and 
unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. These plans are important to 
maintain the health and well-being of the dogs and must be addressed in the written program of veterinary care signed by 
the attending veterinarian. Correct by 9/15/24 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
